text: I appreciate that since I tweetes you, you’ve updated your website and social copy to remove references to yourself as a nonprofit and make clearer that you’re registering people to vote and making endorsements, but... the incorrect representation is out there. Not good.
author: AdamWeinstein

text:
Discourse requires you to say something.

Look. Is this, like a school assignment or something? Are you a single person or a lab team trying to goose a movement? There’s no shame in that. But you need to explain to people what you are, and you’re flatly refusing to do that
author: AdamWeinstein

text: Any reputable organization could make me look awfully foolish by offering some cogent, discrete answers here, and yet all you do is mischaracterize my questions, make vague promises for the future, and ask for a follow
author: AdamWeinstein

text: That’s an unacceptable response. You claim to answer to “the People” (which is a peculiarly incorrect capitalization for an educational org!), but you are refusing to offer any public transparency about your small “incubation.” These are easy questions to answer!
author: AdamWeinstein

text: If you’re seeking a public platform, these are the first questions reporters will ask about your org and cause before assisting you in publicizing them. Do you have any answers for them?
author: AdamWeinstein

text: Why is your only contact info a Twitter account, an IG account, and a Gmail address? Have you sought verification on these platforms? Do you not have a phone or a mailing address? What accountabilities are there for this ostensibly public organization?
author: AdamWeinstein

text: Who, exactly, is making the political endorsements on your website?  None of them are signed. And the most recent post on your site is from just after the November elections. Where’s the educational impact in that?
author: AdamWeinstein

text: You have an online application for partners, but it’s unclear what you will do with these partner leads. What is your theory of change? Who/how many people in your org? What is their founding story? How is this distinct from existing educational orgs? None of this is on your site
author: AdamWeinstein

text: The reason US and state tax codes define non-profit status, *besides* revenue collection, is to give the public faith in those organizations’ meeting certain requirements. What is a “social media startup which is not for profit”? Isn’t that just a social media account?
author: AdamWeinstein

text: Probably 25% of Florida State legacies I’ve known are groovy people, but that’s a big generational tool factory too

text: My undergrad school at Columbia was for part time and working students, so legacies weren’t a thing. The bluebloods were somewhere else while we all stumbled around campus worrying that our admission was a mistake, and someone would surely yank us out of class and send us home
author: AdamWeinstein

text: It feels... like a long, detailed story got pushed into publication early by events; I sort of anticipate a folo

text: I knew some “legacies” in my USNA class who turned out to be incredible people and officers. I knew others who tried for years to get thrown out. The best among them succeeded; the worst ones... almost never miss a promotion board, business scam, or political fundraiser

text: That’s not to say the local guys aren’t all NRA members who read Am. Rifleman, vote a 99.44% straight lobby ticket, and go to the annual meetings; but they’re often vocally unhappy with the direction of the NRA, and that disconnect is palpable
author: AdamWeinstein

text:
The irony is the NRA's big spends on NRATV radicalism can be seen as an attempt to reach out to hardcore local 2A organizers to say "We're with you!" 

To which those guys respond: "I don't need another %#*! Fox News, I need you to whip state legislature votes on open carry"
author: AdamWeinstein

text: One tension that's under-covered on the firearms beat is that between the NRA and smaller national or state 2A orgs. The latter tend to be more aggressive legislatively, and my sense is they think the NRA is too establishment, wasting energy and resources on the TV culture war.
author: AdamWeinstein

text: Spring semester at CJS I quietly took an unpaid internship at the Village Voice, against the school’s enrollment rules. I had more than one (terrific!) professor say I needed to focus less on how to sell my work. But I was terrified of working unpaid *after* graduation
